contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" represents what the witnesses say. It is implied that there must be at least two or three witnesses. Alternate translation: "at the testimony of at least two or three people" or "based on what at least two or three people say happened" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: at the mouth of two witnesses, or at the mouth of three witnesses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hearts" represents people's courage. For a heart to faint is an idiom that means "Do not be afraid." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not let your hearts faint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents a person's courage. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: brother's heart ... his own heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "city" represents the people. Alternate translation: "When you go to attack the people of a city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: When you march up to attack a city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "gates" refers to the city gates. The phrase "open their gates to you" represents the people surrendering and allowing the Israelites to enter their city. Alternate translation: "let you enter their city peacefully" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: open their gates to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "it" refers to the city which represents the people. Alternate translation: "But if the people of the city do not surrender" or "But if the people of the city do not accept your offer of peace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: But if it makes no offer of peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cities" represents the people. Alternate translation: "all the people who live in cities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all the cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "it" refers to the city which represents the people of the city. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: it falls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "in the name of" refers to Yahweh and his authority. Alternate translation: "as one who says and does what Yahweh himself would say and do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" is a metonym for what a person says. Alternate translation: "who will not obey what his father or mother say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who will not obey the voice of his father or the voice of his mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" is a metonym for what a person says or a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: "he will not do what we tell him to do" or "he will not obey us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: he will not obey our voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "Israel" is a metonym for the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "All the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: All Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a symbol for death. Alternate translation: "so that it will not be the fault of your household if someone dies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: so that you do not bring blood on your house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "holy place" is a metonym for the priests who work in the holy place. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "so that the priests in Yahweh's holy place do not take away the whole harvest" or "so that you do not defile the whole harvest and the priests do not allow you to use it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: so that the whole harvest is not confiscated by the holy place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "life" is a metonym for what a person needs to keep himself alive. Alternate translation: "because he would be taking from the man what the man needs to make food for his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for that would be taking a person's life as a pledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "name" is a metonym for the person's family line. Alternate translation: "will continue the family line of that man's dead brother" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will succeed in the name of that man's dead brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "name" is a metonym for the person's family line. Alternate translation: "so that his family line will not disappear from Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: so that his name will not perish from Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" refers to the memory of someone through his descendants. Alternate translation: "refuses to give his brother a son" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: refuses to raise up for his brother a name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" is a metonym for the family. Alternate translation: "who does not give his brother a son and continue his brother's family line" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who does not build up his brother's house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to power or control. Alternate translation: "so the one who struck him will not strike him again" or "from the man who hit him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: out of the hand of him who struck him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "he" is a metonym for "Jacob's descendants." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: There he became

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" refers to the whole person and his cries or prayers. Alternate translation: "he heard our cries" or "he heard our prayers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he heard our voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice of Yahweh" is a metonym for what Yahweh says. Both statements share similar meanings. They emphasize that the person has obeyed all of God's commands. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I have listened to the voice of Yahweh my God; I have obeyed everything you have commanded me to do

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" and "soul" are metonyms for a person's inner being. These two phrases are used together to mean "completely" or "earnestly." See how you translated this in [Deuteronomy 4:29](../04/29.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all your heart and with all your soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "voice of Yahweh" refers to what he says. Alternate translation: "obey what Yahweh your God says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: obey the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "tribes" refers to the people from the tribes of Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin. Alternate translation: "The people from these tribes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: These tribes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "voice of Yahweh" refers to what he says. Alternate translation: "to what Yahweh your God says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israelites used a basket to carry grain. A "kneading trough" was a bowl they used to mix the grain and make bread. Alternate translation: "all the food you grow and all the food you eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your basket and your kneading trough

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "called by the name of Yahweh" means belonging to him. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has called you his own" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: you are called by the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "voice of Yahweh" means what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "what Yahweh your God is saying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites used a basket to carry grain. A "kneading trough" was a bowl they used to mix the grain and make bread. See how you translated this in [Deuteronomy 28:5](../28/05.md). Alternate translation: "all the food you grow and all the food you eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your basket and your kneading trough

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "strength in your hand" refers to power. "Alternate translation: "You will be powerless to do anything about it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: There will be no strength in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "a nation" means the people from a nation. Alternate translation: "people from a nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "voice of Yahweh" are a metonym for what Yahweh said. Alternate translation: "to what Yahweh your God said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nation" is a metonym for the people of that nation. Alternate translation: "a nation whose people have fierce expressions, who do not respect the aged and do not show favor" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a nation with a fierce face that does not respect the aged and does not show favor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "name" refers to Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "Yahweh your God who is glorious and awesome" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: this glorious and fearful name, Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "voice of Yahweh" refers to what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "to what Yahweh says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the voice of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people do have hearts, eyes, and ears. This metonym says that Yahweh has not enabled them to understand from what they saw and heard who Yahweh is, and how and why they should obey him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has not given you a heart to know, eyes to see, or ears to hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" is a metonym representing the people. Alternate translation: "the people of this land, so as to bring on them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: this land, so as to bring on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" is referring to what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "obey what he says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: obey his voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" and "soul" are metonyms for a person's inner being. These two phrases are used together to mean "completely" or "earnestly." See how you translated these words in [Deuteronomy 4:29](../04/29.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all your heart and with all your soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" and "soul" are metonyms for a person's inner being. These two phrases are used together to mean "completely" or "earnestly." See how you translated this in [Deuteronomy 4:29](../04/29.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all your heart and with all your soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" means what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "obey what Yahweh says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: obey the voice of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" and "soul" are metonyms for a person's inner being. These two phrases are used together to mean "completely" or "earnestly." See how you translated this in [Deuteronomy 4:29](../04/29.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all your heart and all your soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the people already know God's commands and can tell them to others. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in your mouth and your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Moses is calling on all those who live in heaven and earth to be witnesses to what he says, or 2) Moses is speaking to heaven and earth as if they are people, and he is calling them to be witnesses to what he says (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.glQuote: I call heaven and earth to witness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" refers to what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "obey what he says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: obey his voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that all of the people of Israel were present. Alternate translation: "in the presence of all the Israelites" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the sight of all Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Moses is calling on all those who live in heaven and earth to be witnesses to what he says or 2) Moses is speaking to heaven and earth as if they are people, and he is calling them to be witnesses to what he says. A similar phrase appears in [Deuteronomy 30:19](../30/19.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.glQuote: call heaven and earth to witness against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the army of the enemy. Alternate translation: "When the Israelites are outside, the enemy army will kill them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Outside the sword will bereave

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents the strength or power of a person. To be exalted is an idiom for defeating an enemy. Alternate translation: "We have defeated them because we are more powerful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Our hand is exalted

contextId.occurrenceNote: "When I sharpen my shining sword." This means God is preparing to judge and punish his enemies. Alternate translation: "When I am ready to judge my enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: When I sharpen my glittering sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses addresses the peoples of all the nations as if they were there listening. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.glQuote: Rejoice, you nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "blood of his servants" represents the lives of his innocent servants who were killed. Alternate translation: "for he will take revenge on his enemies, who killed his servants" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for he will avenge the blood of his servants; he will render vengeance on his enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract noun "life" can be translated as the verb "live." You may need to make explicit the metonymy of obeying the law, which represents the law itself. Alternate translation: "because you will live if you obey it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: because it is your life

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for power and protection. Alternate translation: "you protect all his holy people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all his holy ones are in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice of Judah" refers to the cries and prayers of the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "when the people of Judah pray to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the voice of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses refers to the tribe of Levi as if it were one man. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your faithful one, the one whom you tested ... with whom you struggled

contextId.occurrenceNote: The loins were considered the center of strength, and are here represent strength. Alternate translation: "Take away the strength of" or "Utterly destroy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Shatter the loins of

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "his" refers to Joseph which represents the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "May Yahweh bless their land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: May his land be blessed by Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Jacob's home or 2) Jacob's descendants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob's spring
